text: Handling of Resource Public Key Infrastructure
label: H1

text: This document revises how the Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI) handles Certificate
label: BODY

text: Revocation List (CRL) Number extensions. This document updates RFC 6487.

text: describes the value of the Certificate Revocation List (CRL) Number
label: BODY

text: extension as a monotonically increasing sequence number, which "allows users to easily
label: BODY

text: determine when a particular CRL supersedes another CRL". In other words, in Public Key
label: BODY

text: Infrastructures (PKIs) in which it is possible for Relying Parties (RPs) to encounter multiple
label: BODY

text: usable CRLs, the CRL Number extension is a means for an RP to determine which CRLs to rely
label: BODY

text: In the Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI), a well-formed manifest fileList contains
label: BODY

text: exactly one entry for its associated CRL, together with a collision-resistant message digest of that
label: BODY

text: of the CRL Distribution Points extension in an RPKI Resource Certificate is the same CRL object
label: BODY

text: listed on the issuing Certification Authorities (CAs) current manifest (see
label: BODY

text: ). Together, these properties guarantee that RPKI RPs will always be able to
label: BODY

text: This document clarifies that, in the RPKI, there is exactly one CRL that is appropriate and
label: BODY

text: relevant for determining the revocation status of a given resource certificate. It is the unique
label: BODY

text: the target of the certificate's CRL Distribution Points extension, and
label: BODY

text: listed in the issuing CA's current manifest fileList and has a matching hash (see
label: BODY

text: In particular, a resource certificate cannot be validated without consulting the current manifest
label: BODY

text: unambiguously identify exactly one current CRL for each RPKI CA. Thus, in the RPKI, the
label: BODY

text: ordering functionality provided by CRL Numbers is fully subsumed by monotonically increasing
label: BODY

text: ), thereby obviating the need for RPKI RPs to
label: BODY

text: process CRL Number extensions at all.
label: BODY

text: Therefore, although the CRL Number extension is mandatory in RPKI CRLs for compliance with
label: BODY

text: ), any use of this extension by RPKI RPs merely
label: BODY

text: adds complexity and fragility to RPKI Resource Certificate path validation. This document
label: BODY

text: mandates that RPKI RPs ignore the CRL Number extension.
label: BODY

text: Adjustment of step 5 of the Resource Certification Path Validation.
label: BODY

text: Where two or more CRLs are issued by the same CA, the CRL with the highest value
label: BODY

text: of the "CRL Number" field supersedes all other CRLs issued by this CA.
label: BODY

text: , CAs issue new CRLs using a monotonically
label: BODY

text: increasing sequence number in the "CRL Number" extension. It is
label: BODY

text: that the "CRL Number" match the "manifestNumber" of the manifest that will
label: BODY

text: include the two extensions, Authority Key Identifier and CRL
label: BODY

text: Number, in every CRL that it issues. RPs
label: BODY

text: be prepared to process CRLs with
label: BODY

text: these extensions. No other CRL extensions are allowed.
label: BODY

text: include exactly two extensions in every CRL that it issues: an
label: BODY

text: Authority Key Identifier (AKI) and a CRL Number. No other CRL extensions are
label: BODY

text: ignore the CRL Number extension except for checking that it is marked
label: BODY

text: as non-critical and contains a non-negative integer less than or equal to 2 159 -1.

text: the signature on the CRL is the same public key used to verify the certificate itself.
label: BODY

text: The issuer has not revoked the certificate. A revoked certificate is identified by the
label: BODY

text: certificate's serial number being listed on the issuer's current CRL, as identified by
label: BODY

text: the issuer's current manifest and the CRLDP of the certificate. The CRL is itself valid
label: BODY

text: and the public key used to verify the signature on the CRL is the same public key
label: BODY

text: This document has no additional operational considerations beyond those described in
label: BODY

text: This document explicates that, in the RPKI, the CRL listed on the certificate issuer's current
label: BODY

text: manifest is the one relevant and appropriate for determining the revocation status of a resource
label: BODY

text: certificate. The hash in the manifest's fileList provides a cryptographic guarantee on the
label: BODY

text: Certification Authority's intent that this is the most recent CRL and removes possible replay
label: BODY
